examples.text: I don't know him well; I've only met him twice.
The cows are milked **twice a day**.
He managed to **score twice** in the match.
The book has been turned into film **at least twice** before.
an area twice the size of Wales
Cats sleep twice as much as people.
Charges have risen at twice the rate of inflation.

definitions.definition: an unusual or unpleasant event is not likely to happen in the same place or to the same people twice
after an unpleasant experience you are careful to avoid something similar

examples.text: I don't know her well, I've only met her once or twice.

definitions.definition: to think carefully before deciding to do something

examples.text: You should think twice about employing someone you've never met.
There was enough of the drug in her stomach to kill her twice over.

wordOrigin: late Old English twiges, from the base of two + -s (later respelled -ce to denote the unvoiced sound); compare with once.
